title: Winter Sports
description: How well do you know skiing, skating, hockey, and other winter sports?

questions.question: What is the difference between alpine skiing and cross-country skiing?
options: Alpine is faster, cross-country is longer
Alpine uses one pole, cross-country uses two
Alpine is downhill, cross-country covers flat and varied terrain
questions.explanation: Alpine skiing involves racing down a steep slope, while cross-country skiing involves traveling across flat or varied terrain using your own power for propulsion.

questions.question: In figure skating, what is a 'triple axel'?
options: A jump with 3.5 rotations in the air
questions.explanation: A triple axel is a figure skating jump with 3.5 rotations in the air. It is one of the most difficult jumps because it requires an extra half rotation compared to other triple jumps.

questions.question: What is the Iditarod?
options: An ice fishing competition in Canada
A cross-country ski race in Norway
A long-distance sled dog race in Alaska
questions.explanation: The Iditarod is a long-distance sled dog race held annually in Alaska, covering approximately 1,000 miles from Anchorage to Nome. It commemorates the 1925 serum run to Nome.

questions.question: How many players from each team are on the ice during a standard ice hockey game?
questions.explanation: Six players from each team are on the ice during play: one goaltender, two defensemen, and three forwards (center, left wing, right wing).

questions.question: What is a 'slalom' in skiing?
options: A race weaving between poles or gates
questions.explanation: Slalom is an alpine skiing discipline where skiers navigate a course by weaving between closely spaced poles or gates. It requires quick turns and precise technique.

questions.question: Which country invented the sport of ice hockey?
questions.explanation: Ice hockey originated in Canada in the 19th century. The first organized indoor game was played in Montreal in 1875, and the NHL was founded in 1917.

questions.question: What is the Vasaloppet?
questions.explanation: The Vasaloppet is the world's oldest and longest cross-country ski race, held annually in Sweden since 1922. The 90 km race goes from Salen to Mora, commemorating a journey by King Gustav Vasa in 1521.

questions.question: In speed skating, what is the typical length of a 'short track' oval?
questions.explanation: Short track speed skating takes place on an oval track that is 111.12 meters in circumference, set up on an ice hockey-sized rink. Long track uses a 400-meter oval.

questions.question: What is the 'halfpipe' in snowboarding?
options: A U-shaped channel in the snow for performing aerial tricks
A plumbing technique for making snow
questions.explanation: A halfpipe is a U-shaped channel built in the snow where snowboarders ride back and forth performing aerial tricks on each wall. Olympic halfpipes are typically 22 feet (6.7 meters) high.

questions.question: Which ice hockey trophy is awarded to the NHL champion?
questions.explanation: The Stanley Cup is awarded annually to the NHL playoff champion. Donated by Lord Stanley of Preston in 1893, it is the oldest professional sports trophy in North America.

questions.question: What type of skiing involves jumping off a steep ramp and flying through the air?
questions.explanation: Ski jumping involves skiing down a steep ramp (in-run) and launching off the end to fly as far as possible. The current world record is over 250 meters (820 feet).

questions.question: In which winter sport do competitors slide headfirst on a small sled?
questions.explanation: Skeleton is a sliding sport where competitors ride a small sled headfirst and face-down. It differs from luge, where riders go feet-first and face-up.

questions.question: What are moguls in freestyle skiing?
questions.explanation: Moguls are bumps formed on a steep ski slope. In mogul skiing, athletes navigate a course of moguls while performing aerial tricks, judged on technique, speed, and jump quality.

questions.question: Which legendary figure skater from Norway won three consecutive Olympic gold medals (1928, 1932, 1936)?
questions.explanation: Norwegian figure skater Sonja Henie won three consecutive Olympic gold medals in 1928, 1932, and 1936. She later became a Hollywood movie star and ice show performer.

questions.question: What is 'snowkiting'?
options: Building snow sculptures shaped like kites
Flying a kite in the snow
Using a kite to pull yourself across snow on skis or a snowboard
questions.explanation: Snowkiting involves using a large kite to pull a person across snow while they are on skis or a snowboard. It allows riders to travel uphill and across flat terrain.
